So that's it, that's a wrap! All Quentin Tarantino films done 1-9 (10). Ben it's been a journey that we have gone together, and it's been great reading your reviews and comparing mine to yours to see the difference between ratings and similarities! Brad Pitt is an absolute star and out shadows every cast member in this film, he deserved that Supporting Actor Award (Oscar) he's so charming and witty his role is just so well wrote and cool. It's slow but the lovely aesthetic makes the film amazing, I feel I on a rewatch I will enjoy this further because it's more of a calm loveletter of Quentin Tarantino's filmography, also the countless film references had be amazed for example the "Antonio Margeretti" (which is weird because I've been saying that and Dominic Dacoco all day) just makes it much more entertaining. The ending is so violent but also much more hilarious at the same time. My only disappointments are A- Margot Robbie having 3 mins (practically) on screen, B- it can feel slow at times and it's not your usual Tarantino. Unfortunately since "The Movie Critic" film from Quentin Tarantino was cancelled and (for understandable reasons) he wants to see his son go through the process (that he can remember) he's most likely going to take 5 more years at least. Also I definitely think he won't stop at 10, he's a smart guy and the "10 film" thing is keeping him headlines, I predict he'll say "I want my son to act or blah" to make a few more or 12.

Once Upon a Time... in Hollywood is an instant classic. It's not just a film, but a feeling, a vibe and watching it is an event. The characters are perfectly written. Cliff Booth was my absolute favourite from the start of the film, while I didn't like Rick Dalton at first, but by the end he grew on me. The story is extremely unpredictable. I was surprised to realise that, just like Inglorious Basterds, this is an alteration of a real life event, with both real-life and fictional characters. The dialogues are also perfect. Some of them are quotable classics that I had already come across several times before seeing this film. The cinematography is amazing and very character-driven. The editing is incredible. The movie is about 160 minutes long, but I never wanted it to end, it was never boring. The production design is gorgeous, they captured that time period extremely well. Everything felt authentic. The casting is more than perfect, the star power is incredible and there are so many talented young actors, who became stars after this film. Both Brad Pitt and Leonardo DiCaprio are fantastic, while I loved Margaret Qualley's performance as well. Once Upon a Time... in Hollywood is a perfect, character-driven film surrounded by a story that is inspired by real life events.

If someone were to ask me to lay out the plot of Once Upon A Time In Hollywood, I don't know if I'd be able to coherently do it. I would have to simply say that it's about an actor played by Leonardo DiCaprio living his life with a stunt double played by Brad Pitt, and he somehow ends up fighting Bruce Lee and tossing him into a car. Then there's a weird hippie ranch, and for some reason they attack Brad Pitt while he's high.... And then the movie basically ends there. The movie feels well-made, the scenes are crisp, the dialogue is engaging, there's some good scenes, but honestly I don't really know if the movie has a plot or a resolution or anything like that. Ironically, a movie titled "Once Upon a Time..." doesn't really seem to have a real story to it. I still recommend seeing it, because it's enjoyable, entertaining, and well-made, but I honestly don't know what it's about.

Once Upon a Time... In Hollywood is a signature Tarantino film, packed with big names, stylish direction, and a deep love for old-school Hollywood. The plot? Well, it’s more of a wandering journey than a structured story. Things happen, characters interact, but there isn’t much tying it all together in a traditional sense. That’s expected from Tarantino, he’s more about moments than narratives. The slow-paced intro sets the tone, but it doesn’t really pick up in a way that makes you feel a sense of urgency. The directing is classic Tarantino, with his trademark long conversations, sudden bursts of energy, and, of course, his obsession with feet. The cinematography nails the late '60s aesthetic, from the lighting to the vintage sets, making Hollywood feel alive in every frame. Camera work is bold, sometimes chaotic, but never dull. Acting-wise, DiCaprio and Pitt carry the film effortlessly, delivering performances that feel natural and engaging. The sheer number of recognizable faces adds to the spectacle, making every scene feel like a who’s who of Hollywood. The script has its moments, sharp dialogue and some solid character work, but the comedy often feels forced rather than organic. The soundtrack, however, is one of the film’s strongest elements, blending iconic tracks that perfectly fit the era and mood. Overall, it’s an experience more than a story, and while the pacing drags at times, the world it builds is captivating enough to keep you watching. I wouldn’t call it a masterpiece, but it’s an enjoyable ride if you’re in the mood for something that values atmosphere and performances over a tightly woven plot.

A great movie I thoroughly enjoyed and came back to rewatch. I’d absolutely recommend it if you are a film and pop-culture enthusiast, but that doesn’t mean that the casual viewer won’t appreciate this fine Tarantino movie if they give it a shot. At a surface level, this movie is seemingly a “boring” slice-of-life drama revolving around the famous actor Rick Dalton (Leonardo DiCaprio) and his stunt double Booth Cliff (Brad Pitt); however to those who have got a keen eye for detail there is a lot more to delve into. Here’s a few of the many things I love about this movie: the satirical representation of Hollywood and Western Movies, the plethora of historical and movie references, the cinematic and colorful depiction of Los Angeles during the late sixties and early seventies, DiCaprio and Pitt’s great performances, as well as the signature touches that scream “This is a Quentin Tarantino Movie,” such as the masterfully written dialogue, and of course (hate it or love it) the plethora of feet, which usually I would find disgusting, but since it is is Tarantino it is amusing to see one of his signature quirks. Overall a very solid film that has plenty of rewatch value, since I noticed so many more details the second time around, and I know I’ll find something I missed if I watch it a third time too and I still won’t get bored because there is so much going on despite the slower yet appropriate pace which contributes to a longer runtime. 8.5/10

A pretty fun and laid-back love letter to late 1960s Hollywood, where the end of the golden era of film is approaching while the experimental counterculture era is emerging on the horizon. Brad Pitt and Leonardo DiCaprio are both very funny and likeable in their lead roles. Margot Robbie plays a nice and subtle homage to Sharon Tate, only highlighting her happy everyday life and how things could be if that one fateful night never happened. Bruce Lee's bit is kind of a letdown though. The movie has a charming laid-back vibe when presenting all these people of Hollywood just living their everyday lives. A real slice of life from the upper crust. A good middle chunk of the movie kind of drags on and overstays it's welcome, but luckily it all pays off in the jarringly violent final confrontation that chooses to rewrite history with the Manson killers. It's not my favorite Tarantino film by a long shot, but its still very likeable and entertaining if you stay patient and smell the golden roses.

The title sorts of gives it away, but not directly. This is not history, but a fairy tale... a "What If" tale. Marvel comics used to do "What If?" books. What if Uncle Ben had not died in front of Peter Parker? What if the Hulk had always retained the brain of Bruce Banner? That really what Tarentino has done. Even more than a "What If" it is an "I wish." It is awesome and hilarious and we wish it was the true history. How wonderful it would have been had the Mansons walked into the wrong house. Five stars if not for the opening scenes.

Anyone that was alive when the Tate/LaBianca murders occurred remembers how horrific it was that 7 innocent souls were snuffed out in 1 hour of madness... I was a Sharon Tate fan even as a kid so her murder particularly affected me and all through my life I've thought about the "What If's" that could have taken place that could have kept her and the others safe from Manson's madness. She and the others would have simply went on with their lives and today she's be a Little Ole'Grandma now and would have had a fantastic acting career. This movie is emotionally satisfying because the victims of that sick bunch of useless people were spared the horrors of a tragic end. We all know it's not real life but I think Quentin Tarantino did a great job bringing this alternate version of reality to the public eye. Brad and Leo had great chemistry and Margot Robbie fit the part extremely well. All the actors played their part to bring together a great motion picture. Great job from everyone involved creating this wonderful movie.

👍🏻74% Many conflicting feelings about this one… I really liked the first half, it had many homages to Hollywood and pretty engaging storylines. I did quickly lose interest in the second half as it all felt pointless and meaningless. The characters were still fun to watch but the storylines weren't as engaging, connected, and honestly as entertaining as the first half. The ending was crazy and great, but I do think that leading up to that, Tarantino falls into the issues I had with Pulp Fiction, the lack of direction and purpose. I don't know if I didn't get the message of the film, but I was a bit disappointed. It's still a pretty positive score because it's incredibly well made and often very entertaining. The film looks amazing. The production design, costumes, colors, and the camera movement come together to perfectly create the feeling of the late 1960s'. I also think Leo is brilliant here, balancing the great dialogue we've come to expect from Tarantino, with genuine emotion. Brad Pitt's Oscar win was warranted. He is hilarious and so immersed into the character to a point where I truly loved every time he was on screen, even when the scene itself doesn't move the plot much forward. The rest of the cast is also great, with stand-outs being Margot Robbie and Feyd-Rautha himself, Austin Butler. And also, just having Tarantino show his love for movies, with his extravagant style a bit more toned down, but still keeping it cool, is just a gift to movie fans today. I don't think this is one of Tarantino's best, but it's still a very worthy addition to his filmography.

This could have been a 30 min short film, and it would have the exact same effect as the current, almost 3h time-waster. It's an amazing cast, led by an amazing director, and somehow this movie fails to keep the viewers' attention, and when it grabs it, it just throws it in the bin.

If you are a fan of Quentin Tarantino and the golden age of Hollywood movies, and movies in general, then this movie will certainly be for you. I think the negative reviews fail to realise what this movie really is. Just like Nolan's "Oppenheimer", a biopic of not only Dr Robert Oppenheimer himself, but science and the development of the atomic bomb, so too is Tarantino's "Once upon a time in Hollywood" a biopic of Hollywood cinema and movie making, the culture and the actors. I think if you watch this movie with that in mind, it changes your perspective upon viewing the movie. Honestly, give it a watch, Brad Pitt and DiCaprio giving some of the finest performances of their careers. The casting choice here is excellent as the old age of the Hollywood movie star era is coming to an end, and they perfectly fit the narrative of this.

A story about a sad time in Hollywood history that weaves itself around the Charles Manson family, a western star in the nadir of his career, his stunt double, Roman Polanski and his wife Sharon Tate. I have returned for reviews! Once upon a time in Hollywood is a 5 year old Tarantino tribute to the last year of the Hollywood golden age that revolves around the imagination and the reality combined. Just a really easy film to watch (except for the end of course), regarding: friendship, quotes and all round great storytelling. I remember watching this on the plane to Istanbul, thinking about this long after I landed which I think is what the film is really good at. The acting too is quite reminiscent of the 60's style and I really liked the idea about these 2 guys traveling around, which is all I really want from Tarantino: no story but great dialogue and a way to meltdown a few hours. While I wouldn't say I'd like Quentin, he has done not so great films that dwell on the complete opposites of what I want from him. But that's what his fans want I guess; a forgettable rendering of old nostalgia. But in terms of Once upon a time in Hollywood, it creates a feel good movie of not only nostalgia but heart and thoughts after viewing, which makes this his best in my personal preference. Only flaw is... lack of wrapping up! The film needed to bring all the big cast's stories to wrap up. Maybe they could of had them all together or something but this might be up to your imagination. Overall, cinema tributes at it's full force, Once upon a time in Hollywood creates fulfilling entertainment expertly thanks to a brilliant cast and one of the shining examples of how to make a film memorable. Grade: A+

Love him or hate him, Tarantino is a creative genius. Personally, I think he's a director who ranks with some of the best. But he is marmite: you either love him, or hate him and each one of his films are split into categories of 'excellent' or 'poor' by critics but very rarely in between the two. This latest entry seems to follow suit. 'Once Upon A Time In... Hollywood' is set in the late sixties at the height of the notorious cult commanded by Charles Manson and primarily follows actor, Rick Dalton who is desperately trying to reclaim and retain his golden status on screen and his best friend and stunt double, Cliff Booth, now turned general dogsbody. So what's my personal take on this film? Well, this is Tarantino as I have not seen him before. Of course, the cast (which includes stalwarts of any Tarantino film) are all given his usual, cutting-edge, trademark dialogue which has become infamous. Brad Pitt (Cliff Booth) and Leonardo Dicaprio, (Rick Dalton) make an exceptional on-screen pairing, bouncing off of each other seemlessly. DiCaprio's portrayal of an actor whose light is slowly flickering out is at times poignant but this is immediately offset by Pitt's comedic approach. Being that without Dicaprio's 'Dalton', Pitt's 'Booth' is destined to be even more forgotten than his peer, this humour, whether intentional or not, should be frowned upon, but for some reason it just works. Ultimately, it is these two actors that will leave their mark on audiences... NOT the inclusion of Sharon Tate or the Manson family. Margot Robbies' performance of Tate has been heavily criticised and Tarantino has been attacked on not giving her more dedicated screen time or more dialogue. Personally, I think her casting and performance presents a sense of trepidation to the film which captivates us. In reality, her violent murder shook the world to the bare bones and ended the golden age of Hollywood for many. For those of us who know her fate, it's actually difficult at times to watch her enjoying herself, or to hear near the end, 'Out of time' by The Rolling Stones play: her's was a life taken too soon at the beginning of what could have been an illustrious career that quite possibly could have gone down in the annals of history very differently. But this is Quentin Tarantino, and his film's title begins with, 'Once upon a time...' and just as World War 2 was reimagined in his 'Inglourious Basterds', Sharon Tate's demise is given a fairytale ending that should strike a chord within all of us. And it is this which sets aside this 9th entry from Tarantino to his previous releases. This movie has heart. It is Tarantino, reaching back to that fateful year, that terrifying night, and wishing that he could rewrite it. Very much so in a way that we wish so too. Even the trademarked violence that we acknowledge will be present in any of his works is watered down. And when the climactic ending does begin rolling, you find yourself practically cheering at the screen. So, with a scolding hot soundtrack accompanying the beautifully shot backdrop of 1969, I genuinely believe this to be one of Tarantino's best films. Do I believe it to be misunderstood? Yes. Do I believe that in years down the line people will reflect upon it? Most certainly. But regardless of any review, audiences are going in droves to watch it which raked in an incredible $41 million (£39 million) on its opening weekend in the USA alone. And so the wait begins for what will next be his 10th and, as stated by the director himself, final directorial feat?

Let's talk about the 9th film by Quentin Tarantino is Once Upon a Time in Hollywood or is it the 10th film, I don't know. If you call it the 9th film by him, it doesn't make sense if you call it that without missing one movie by Tarantino or the fact you called Kill Bill: Volume 2 the 4th film instead of the 5th film by lingering Part 1 & 2 together and then call it the 4th film by Quentin Tarantino even that really is convoluted to say the least. But after I reviewed Pulp Fiction which I think it's one of Quentin Tarantino's masterpiece and now with Once Upon a Time in Hollywood on our hands, this one goes on the different route. This one is taken in Hollywood. It has come to the official point of view Quentin is making a 10th film which says to be his final film, The Movie Critic. If I get the chance to see it, I'll be sure to welcome to it. All right, let's get on with it. An actor and a stuntman, Rick Dalton and Cliff Booth played by Leonardo DiCaprio and Brad Pitt, are navigating the rapidly changing film industry. Rick's agent, Marvin Schwarz, advises him to make Spaghetti Westerns in Italy. He gets upset about this and Cliff Booth cheers him up and he still doing the western show, Bounty Law. The next morning, Rick is doing a TV Western, Lancer in the movie set, Cliff is visiting the hippies after fixing Rick's antenna on top of his house. Upon seeing the other films by Tarantino I am so looking forward to reviewing them just like I did with the others by David Fincher and Martin Scorsese. And if that movie I am doing is going to interest you, let me give you a recommendation in that factor. Margot Robbie is Sharon Tate, a real-life actress who stars in Valley of the Dolls and she is in love with Roman Polanski. She's got nothing to do apart from going to the Playboy Mansion with Roman Polanski and goes to the cinema, that's it. And if you believe in that factor, then let me give you the recommendation. Alrighty, let's see what we got here. If you a fan of Margot Robbie or you have the hot's for her, you should go and see her with Leonardo DiCaprio in The Wolf of Wall Street. If you can't get enough of her, go and see her with Brad Pitt in Babylon. (I mean, who wouldn't?) If you a huge fan of Quentin Tarantino like I am recently, go and check out Brad Pitt in Inglourious B*****ds. If you are obsessed with the director, check out Leonardo DiCaprio in Django Unchained. And if you really wanna get the inspiration of wanting to see both actors together with the director, go check out Once Upon a Time… in Hollywood. (Chuckles) And if that's not enough, let me tell you what's really surprising. If you love Scarface and The Godfather trilogy, Al Pacino is in it. Hooray! Along with Kurt Russell. For a film by Quentin Tarantino, the violence doesn't kick in until the very end so nothing in it is really that disturbing or gratuitous to be exact. For a movie that is a two hour and a half running time, much like more movies I've seen that is nearly three hours is one those that's just a lot of fun. Something that is impeccable, something that is groundbreaking, something that has a lot of potential. Once Upon a Time in Hollywood is a masterful piece of filmmaking that's taken place in 1960's is an improvement from what Quentin Tarantino achieved. The acting is impressive, the cinematography is top-notch, the story is improving and the directing style is immense. I love Quentin Tarantino as a director. He is phenomenal! But I still wish he hadn't retire from movies after the 10th film he was going to do but I can't imagine why. I don't think Tarantino ever made a bad film. Never in his life he has. But what can I say? It's all down to the creativity he has. It is one of the best films of 2019. I f**king love Once Upon a Time… in Hollywood.

I can't be unbiased when it comes to Tarantino's movies, but Once Upon a Time... in Hollywood is just as unique in its writing, cinematography and craftsmanship as any of his previous wild creations. Delightfully unrestrained, with masterful pacing that allows a lively, breathing, picturesque exposition before twisting the proverbial knife with a fitting peripeteia; a torrent of indulgent but purposeful violence, a fiery crescendo unleashed before the audience's eyes... It's a fitting, nostalgic, and colorful ode to a point in time at one place, wonderfully enriched with a signature touch of insanity---this film has it all. If it is truly to be the last from the trailblazing icon that is Quentin Tarantino, it shall be the most honorable of discharges.

It truly is brilliant. Tarantino, once again, cleverly mashes history, cinema, and his brain into another fascinating and funny film. It's cinematography and coloring bring hippie color schemes and 1960s L.A. to life. It's Academy-Award-winning production design is on-point and never fails to impress. It's writing is witty and its story is unforgettable. Not to mention, Tarantino leads an absolutely wonderful cast. Leonardo DiCaprio and Brad Pitt, however, are the true highlights. I was baffled at how they seemed like they had really been best friends for what seemed a lifetime. DiCaprio never ceases to amaze whether he's crying over his roles and his soul, taunting little girls as a villainous cowboy, or dead-drunk as a rich actor. Brad Pitt beautifully balances both the personality of a caring friend and a cool dude with perfect comedic-timing and some of the film's best lines. I loved the film's silliness, grittiness, attention-to-detail, its telling of the times, and telling of a new tale. Its hard to think of another movie that is anything like Once Upon A Time In…Hollywood (except maybe another Tarantino film).

This is Tarantino's best film so far, and any nay-sayers who say it's bad or poorly written are just feeling targeted by the film's wit and sensibilities. Go into it as blind as you can and just enjoy the ride. This film is for movie lovers.

Rated R: for revisionist history fever dreams. Not suitable for IQ's over 100. I seriously think Quinton has some deep psychological issue to keep writing this kind of revisionist crap. Does it make him feel better? It's just really, really weird. You usually don't see this kind of detachment from reality outside of a cartoon or superhero movie. For me it just doesn't work because I have a brain. I didn't cheer when the good guys killed the Nazis in Inglorious Bastards. I just found it completely stupid. Same with this horrible ending. Unless you are doing major world building then rewriting major historical events in isolation is just, really, really stupid and more then a little bit weird. Outside of that there is pretty much zero plot here. Just following around a has been actor and his tough guy lap dog until the final fever dream at the end. It's DiCaprios worst performance in a while. The accent is just awful. Pitt does more with a single look than 100 lines from DiCaprio. But then Pitts sycophantic, tough guy character is not very believable. To be believable he would have had to punch DiCaprio's character right in the face several times because no self respecting person would endure DiCaprios constant sniveling. Margot Robbie is in it but has so little screen time you'll forget all about her. Just seemed like a total waste of talent. At least he resisted going to Spahn ranch and killing Charlie with a flame thrower in the end.

I enjoy a nostalgic setting and seeing how life was not that long ago. If you expect frenetic edits and multiple explosions per frame you will be disappointed. If you know what REALLY happened, you will instantly recognize the tension from the horror that is to come. It is enough to hold the viewer in anticipation -- they will wait patiently to see how Cliff Booth is going to tear apart the Manson thugs. My only beef with any QT film is that he stays in that revenge zone a bit too long. It feels good to repay evil with suffering. The questions is: how much can a good person punish evil, without himself becoming evil? One effective head bash is sufficient in most cases, but doing it over and over just makes the protagonist look like a fiend. Perhaps QT has been holding up that mirror to teach that fact. I feel good when I should feel shame.

Once Upon a Time…In Hollywood dishes out the best and worst of what Quentin Tarantino has to offer. Centered around the relationship between fading actor Rick Dalton (Leonardo DiCaprio) and his stuntman Cliff Booth, the film is a nostalgic look at Hollywood culture during the summer of 1969. On the positive side, the characters are relentlessly interesting, the story is original, the acting is great, the dialogue is fantastic, the soundtrack is spot on, and Tarantino's visual style (lots of effective tracking shots, crane shots, etc) is evident at all times. The primary negative issue is the bloated 159 minute running time, thanks to Tarantino's inclusion of scenes that are either too long or totally unnecessary and the ridiculous number of cutaway shots of the cultural detritus of the time, giving the impression that he is more interested in entertaining himself than he is in entertaining the audience. It's good, but it should have been great.

The characters / acting and numerous odes to the Golden Age of Hollywood keep this movie engaging. And just as you wonder where it's going, everything comes together and concludes in classic Tarantino style.

If you've got three very long hours to carve out, "Once Upon a Time...in Hollywood" is a fun wallow through Tarantino's alt-history of the Manson murders, together with a nostalgic look at 60s Tinsletown. Tarantino's most accessible flick, it's a must-see for history buffs and cinephiles, but watch it on video to pause for yawns and a ninth inning stretch.

Arguably Tarantino's most restrained picture may also be his most tedious, at least as far as wide audience appeal is concerned. Not only is this is a fairly slow paced movie, it is a film where one certainly feels its legnth. The majority of the film is split between Leo DiCaprio's pitiable Rick Dalton, a former movie and tv cowboy star, now washed up and looking for a second wind; and his best friend/stuntman/chauffeur Cliff Booth, played by the always charismatic Brad Pitt. Together they go about their day-to-day lives in 1969 Hollywood, and really thats about it. The film masterfully plays with audiences expectations, especially those familiar with certain tragic events set to take place one fateful night in August involving Rick's neighbor, Sharon Tate, endearingly played by Margot Robbie. In Tarantino's Hollywood there is an ever-looming threat one cannot escape from, and not just from the hippies. One never truly feels safe, as though the ball could drop at any given moment, and Tarantino knows that we have come to expect this. So instead he builds up tension for 2 hours before pulling the figurative trigger and delivering exactly what we want.

One of Quentin Tarantino's lighter movies, the more character-driven Once Upon a Time in Hollywood has great dialogue, well-defined characters performed masterfully well be they real or fictitious, a memorably unsettling sequence at what is known as the Manson Ranch, amsuing sense of humour, wonderfully realised, immersive production values and one heck of an ending (if admittedly derivative of a past non-Western Tarantino period piece). It's not for everybody and the nearly-three-hour runtime will test the patience of viewers who aren't into Leonardo DiCaprio chatting with a precocious 8-year-old girl (well-written scene by the way) but, after the disappointment that was The Hateful Eight, what might be Quentin Tarantino's penultimate directorial effort proves, as far as people who still like his work are concerned, that the man's still got it.
Not Tarantino's best, but found it a thoroughly entertaining film.

Though advertised as an accurate biographical account of the Manson Murders in 1960s Hollywood, this film is actually more fictional, less about these murders and more a love letter to the actors of that time. The story is centred around director Roman Polanski and wife Sharon Tate's fictional neighbour, actor Rick Dalton and his stunt man Cliff Booth (based screen legends Steve McQueen and Burt Reynolds and the latter's stunt-double Hal Needham). The film explores how the two are struggling to adapt to the ever-changing Hollywood, paralleling with the growth of the Manson family who are interested with the Tate/Polanski household. Though a long film, it does quite well at showcasing the struggles of actors in Hollywood, the indulgence of the rich and the rise of a fanatic cult.

Sorted by efforts on screen in this disrespect for the victims of the Charles Manson murders in the 1960s: Brad Pitt, Leonardo Di Caprio, Dakota Fanning, Margot Robbie and in last place TARANTINO!!. 2/10

With a title like Once Upon A Time... In Hollywood, knowing of Tarantino's great passion for cinema, my expectations were high. For its three hours of running time, what we got is a sleepy bedtime story glued together with a bunch of mediocre sketches of dead celebrities not saying or revealing anything compelling. If you're still awake, you will be treated to another of Tarantino's over the top signature finales. You know...The total destruction of the bad guys. Dog mauling, flame thrower and all.
It's a strange one, as sometimes it feels like it doesn't have a point, and yet it's still interesting. Probably my favorite Tarantino movie. I don't like his stranger stuff.

What could've been another masterpiece in Tarantino's line up ends up suffering from some of the worst pacing I've ever seen and a lack of engaging storytelling. Once Upon a Time in Hollywood has one banger cast and two lovable leads, Leonardo DiCaprio, Brad Pitt, Margot Robbie, they all give it their all and it's one of this movie's redeeming qualities that saves it from being completely abysmal. The setting of 60's Hollywood is quite clever and allows our stars to pull off some wacky scenes. However, quirky characters and excellent chemistry can only get you so far, as the pacing is truly god awful, the first 3 quarters of this movie are slow as molasses with barely any plot development, and then once we actually get to the final act, it switches into its highest gear and blazes through it at the speed of light. Still, the final act of the movie is the best as it finally feels like something important is happening with even more funny interactions. Once Upon a Time in Hollywood has everything in place to deliver an exciting look-back on old school Hollywood, but would improve tenfold with a bit of an overhaul such as a new cut that trims down this slog of a movie.

A fun character study movie, but the plot and the end in particular felt like wishful thinking. It strikes me as not the kind of movie a confident director would make, and Tarantino's own insecurities show through as a denial rather than a confession.

A darkly funny and entertaining picture, and surprising return to form for Tarantino. This is surely his best directed feature since Pulp Fiction. The performance from Leonardo DiCaprio is simply outstanding, particularly when he convincingly pulls off playing a man acting badly. The film is also directed with great class, with an excellent script that expertly blends real and fictitious history, with a great homage to the late Sharon Tate. Once Upon a Time in Hollywood manages to successfully recreate the Los Angeles landscape in a late 1960s setting, and do so in a way very pleasing to the eye.

There's self-indulgence and there's gluttony. With some films you feel that they're perhaps 10 minutes too long. Here, there's a whole hour that could have been cut without losing anything. After all, there isn't much to lose when the entire film is made up of sub plots. Pretty much the whole of Dicaprio's role is pointless. Pitt, though, has fun and holds the film together with a casual swagger that suggests that something may come of the film. It doesn't, but while he's on screen, you don't mind so much

In the grand scheme of Tarantino Movies, this one doesn't float my boat as well as the rest. Sure, there is a maturity to this film that shows growth, and there's no doubting that this is a movie that is probably more personal to QT than his other endeavours, but it's a difficult one to compare to the rest of his back catalogue. It's certainly not gritty like Resevoir Dogs, or as cult as Pulp Fiction. It's not as comedic as Jackie Brown. Overall, it doesn't enthrall like these movies. There are times when the film becomes too long in the tooth. Scenes showing the acting on set of Rick Dalton at times feel needless and add little to the storyline. It also feels TOO restrained at times and really only nods to QTs more gloriously over-dramatic style towards the last 20 minutes. What is done well though is Quentin's ability to lead your thought process one way and then turn it around - or drop the idea dead. There are times when you think "yeah, this will lead to ..." Only to have there be no lead there at all. Also done well is the usage of an all-star cast in bit parts without the appearances feeling like little Camo performances to bring a big name to a film. Again, truly a nod to the greatness of Tarantino in that he can bring in massive names for small parts and leave the audience fulfilled. You have to watch this if you like to watch movies by Quentin Tarantino, but equally if you're a fan of any of the lead stars too. And if you're not, it's still a good film to watch. But if you're looking for classic Tarantino with a lot of action and a storyline that makes you think hard - you're in for a bit of a shock.

Not to mention, the fantastically brutal fight scene in the climax of the film.

The film adopts a nostalgic profile that is VERY well constructed, with maximum excellence. The crisis of identity and the way cinema works is the maximum point of Tarantino's personal touch in the film and certainly the best part of it.

The movie QT has been building to his entire career, it's a brilliant, wildly thrilling, completely original, and deeply resonant piece of storytelling that only a great pop artist can create after their voice has evolved over the course of 25 years. It's the best movie of the past decade, one of the best of this century, so far, and a sterling reminder of just how great, resonant, inspiring and unforgettable movies can be when the corporations just get out of the way and let a gifted artist do his thing when he's truly in tune with and channeling the desires and impulses that fuel his creativity. The cast is also perfect. The character of Cliff Booth is one of the best creations of recent memory. It's also the best use of Brad Pitt in a movie ever.

While I have great respect for him, I can't watch all Tarantino movies due to the gore. So this was do-able, and I found the flame-thrower pool scene near the end particularly gratifying. This boy's got Southern roots, and it comes out in his pacing, his humor, and his economy of words. I'm good with all of that. So much of what he does isn't even all that good, it's just weird - with great soundtracks and kitsch and casts and budgets. And that's enough of a contrast to what we usually get, so I'm also good with that. It's a funny movie that I thoroughly enjoyed. I was also a bit horrified at how well, and frequently, DiCaprio hocks loogies, and the dexterity with which he handles cigarettes, lighters, and the way he can hold and spew smoke on command almost like it's a dialogue unto itself. It's literally physical comedy, loogies aside - that boy prob has a habit he doesn't need. But gracious, he's good at it. There's almost a juvenile aspect to most Tarantino movies, that when added to big boy resources, just works. I can enjoy some caricature. And I don't understand why everyone else is derivative but him….. I mean, I think everything at this point is largely derivative, I don't consider that a problem, just don't understand all the discrepancies in application. Maybe this is Tarantino for the masses, I dunno, but I thought it was delightful and got a lot of laughs and enjoyment from it. Think you just need to kinda know what you're getting. Some movies are so good they rate a re-watch, and if you're lucky, that re-watch reveals new layers & details you hadn't appreciated the first time around. So I find it with "Once Upon a Time...". First is the immaculately detailed and richly nostalgic look, sound, & feel of the late 60's; a decade that began with so much hope & promise, but which was starting to turn "bad" by 1969, even if a callow young college student like myself didn't recognize the shift happening at the time. Next is the level of thought & creativity Tarantino put into the story line of the fictitious Western TV series "Bounty Law", that prefaces the decline of Rick Dalton's Hollywood career. The movie puts enough "hooks" into this that I actually hope Tarantino does indulge his clearly well-thought out fantasy to make a real film or a pilot around "Bounty Law". I for one would watch it! Lastly, thanks Quentin for NOT running us through the real ending to the Sharon Tate story one more time. I wish you could have written the "endings" for the whole damn decade. We'd live in a much better world today if you could have!

The chemistry between Pitt and DiCaprio is really nice, and Pitt's character is particularly compelling without necessarily being redeemable. The politics of the movie feel troubling ... particularly, advancing the narrative in which the Manson family stands in for hippiedom, and there is some kind of a culture war between hippies and, well, old-school Hollywood cowboy white guys who stand in for the norm. Having forgotten about the history, I found the class stuff at the end more remarkable than Tate. (Pitt goes to the hospital; DiCaprio goes to a party.) The movie gave me more I wanted to keep thinking about than I realized at the time.

Tarantino's inversion of the historical account offers a glimpse into the fairy tale universe where the "real" Hollywood tough guys get to make the leap into "new Hollywood". Sharon Tate's Kung fu is a sham but here in this dream world, the rough men intercept the psycho cultists and put the world right with nothing but a can of dog food and a flamethrower. A sweet dream of the spirit transformed from the "real" Hollywood circa 1969, described by Joan Didion in her famous book The White Album, a world of darkness, of bands "too cool" like the Doors, a world where no one was surprised when Manson crashed the party with his massacre, this world of "new Hollywood" gets a makeover. Manson is described as the flipside of charismatic cult leader, a loser who shows up at the Polanski residence looking for Terry Melcher (a fact according to at least one witness) but this is all you get from this cosmic nobody. This fairy tale rings true and I think it's Tarantino's best picture, better than Pulp Fiction by a mile, a love letter to a world that never was.

Once Upon A Time...In Hollywood - 9/10. It's definitely not for a film for everyone. The film takes its time in terms of moulding the story and tempo, but it delivers a cool nostalgic trip to the year 1969. Quentin Tarantino has crafted a film with much detail and superb performances! Leo and Brad deliver some solid and hilarious performances, with a shining Margot Robbie giving a subtle and bright performance as Sharon Tate. The rest of the ensemble cast deliver some great performances in their limited screen time, with Austin Butler and Margaret Qualley delivering standout performances within the ensemble cast. And, surprisingly, the film is probably his least violent film. I consider it as one of his best works, and definitely his most funniest film. A definite must watch!

A fantastic period piece from Tarantino. Toned down shock and quirkiness making for a more enjoyable overall experience. Memorable performances from Pacino and Pitt - probably my all-time favorite by Pitt. Tarantino has found yet another film to blend the western theme with a contemporary subject. And yes, Nazis get fragged in this film as well.

A Tarantino-esq. look at the Manson murder of Sharon Tate. Also a look at the changing dynamic in entertainment and American culture from the traditional norms of the 50's-60's into the hippie era of the 70's. There are a lot of layers here. The dialogue is always crisp. The acting is superb. DiCaprio and Pitt are great in the dynamics of their relationships. Margot Robbie is unappreciated in her mesmerizing performance as Sharon Tate. The entire supporting case from Margaret Qualley, Bruce Dern, Al Pacino, and the rest are phenomenal. Mike Moh is funny and exciting as "Bruce Lee". Forget all the controversy from people that can accept an altered version of history that has Hitler burned alive but can't accept an over the top Bruce Lee- this was memorable. The movie soundtrack is worth the whole thing even if you aren't a fan of the actual film. You do not need to know the real version of events to watch this but you will smile if you do.

Once Upon Upon a Time In Hollywood – Even The Name is another ‘Borrowing' QT's latest indulgence is all about his one-way fixation with the ‘60s. At 160+ mins it's a long trudge but the script probably only had few pages if compared with other movies of this length, why?... So many scenes are made up of shots of bods getting into cars, then long internal shot from back seat (lifted from the far better Gun Crazy' 50s) then bods get out of car, long shots of feet walking, more bods get into cars, more long internal driving shot, bods again get out of car, more feet walking. This format is repeated from beginning to end –pages of same-- The 60s heralded in a new low for movie making – features like; ‘Beach Blanket Bingo', ‘How to Stuff a Wild Bikini ', ‘Sergeant Deadhead' were playing as main features across the land, el-cheapo's had become the new norm. What would usually have been a ‘B' picture were now being sold as an ‘A'. Yes. it may have helped a jaded Hollywood at that time but what about other mainstream audiences? So, what might have influenced TQs fixation with this downturn in the social morays of movies? Tarantino grew up in the swinging ‘60s/mod ‘70s working in a porn cinema (this perhaps explains his addiction to perversity) including a video store - while also watching the endless re-runs of TV shows, along with an overflowing barrage of low budget, Spaghetti westerns that had flooded the market - thank goodness some audiences grew up (well, some did) and demanded better. These endless ‘homage's to days offering little more than cheap TV-style quickies -- now being released to the big screen --- with product that was generally catering for a guideless, acid tripping youth (such as the Manson crew, etc) wanting endless simple-minded partying. Hollywood producers loved it – now, for half the normal budgets, they were getting the same financial returns as quality features. QT has simply revived those days and a new ‘comic book hero' generation have picked it up. Only this time round, the budgets are BIGGER while the contents remain juvenile, if not ridiculous. Trouble is, too many of today's producers and art critics also grew up in this overly comfortable, ‘anything goes' era, so they wrap on about the glorious emptiness that's making them all rich. Some rave about the cinematography and design - with that much money being thrown about it's simple to ‘copy' the work of previous Masters. But, no matter how expensively dressed-up and stylishly packaged rubbish maybe, it's still rubbish (but, GOOD-LOOKING rubbish). Too much you might be saying? Take a look back, revisit many of those poorly scripted, badly acted, TV shows and movies of the 50s-60s – the ones Q.T. tends to dote over...you may be surprised how your memory may have failed you as just how poor most were. Once U.A.T.I.H. looks like several proposed projects that never got off the ground all edited into one, and doesn't do justice to any of them. One or two characters and situations looked as if they may have been leading to something but simply fizzled out. How long might it take before more look back and ask, how were we so fooled? Or is it just that LESS has now become the new MORE? So, if this is Q.Ts 9th may there be only one left to go. Please.

As someone who has liked, disliked and loved some of Tarantino's previous work, and someone who's an avid consumer of quality cinema, I went in with some hype, some skepticism and mixed expectations. I had a slight idea what the movie was about, but I never bothered to dig deep into it before actually watching it. And since I believe I could've enjoyed it much more had I looked up the whole story prior, I highly recommend you do. It won't spoil the fun for you, it'll add up to it. So I sat there, doing my best to just enjoy the movie instead of being too critical of it and looking too far into the scenes than I probably should, which certainly made for a better, more relaxed experience. The movie is long, and it being somewhat slow paced and patience demanding (which we're not always used to from Tarantino) could make it feel even longer, but if you're into that like I am, you know that's where the fun is at. I smiled effortlessly at most of the scenes (because they were just THAT good) and even laughed with some of them, but one thing is sure, in classic Tarantino fashion, the writing and dialogue were absolutely ON POINT. The casting could not have been better, each actor portrayed their character to mere perfection and they felt more like actual people than in any other movie I've seen. Then comes the storyline, And I can't help but be a little biased here, seeing as my favorite movies are those that do nothing more than just tell you a story, the ones that make no effort to keep your attention. There's some events going on that you just have to follow, even if they feel like they're not leading to any peak or climax. This movie is a PRIME example of that. Perfect for people who like to get invested in a film rather than have it reward or gratify them. And then it ended, leaving me, and everyone there I'm sure, STUNNED by what we had just seen, by how brilliant it all was and wishing we could watch the whole thing over again, there and then. It was a truly surreal experience.
It's nostalgic and the fights are composed very well. I heard about the California hippie culture back in the day but this movie gives the experience of how bad it was.

It doesn't work as breezy or mindless fun because of how bored I was, and it doesn't work as a compelling narrative or character study because it's clearly not trying to be. https://letterboxd.com/josephtomastik/film/once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood/

You don't hit "play" on a Tarantino picture with conventional expectations. I was perhaps surprised at how considered and thoughtful the script is, pacing slowly (but consistently) through a blend of real people and absolute fiction smoothly. It felt like it was building towards making a big point, but instead descends into hugely rewarding carnage - which isn't a criticism. In fact, the payoff for your patience and calmness is for jarringly brilliant (and potentially gratuitous) violence. If this is Quentin's last film, he's going out on a high.

Tarantino did a good bait-and-switch on me with this one, although the movie title should've tipped me off. I watched this knowing next to nothing about it, and I know only the bare minimum about the real-world events, but when Sharon Tate and Polanski showed up, I felt pretty sure about the direction this was going (which is exactly what Tarantino wanted I guess). When *that* night approached, with the the time-and-date overlays, I was convinced this was a story based on true events with a few fictional characters thrown in the mix. Needless to say, I was oh-so-wrong. After the slow and deliberate build-up, in the last chapter of the movie you get treated to a very abrupt and jarring transition into Tarantino territory. And then when the credits roll, the next surprise to me was that the movie almost has a feel-good happy end. Performances are top-notch, and without knowing much about the setting, the meticulous attention to detail is obvious. I enjoyed this plunge into the late sixties immensely, and the cathartic burst of violence at the end was the cherry on top.

Ritorna la scrittura graffiante di Tarantino in un film molto più pacato del solito. Questa volta il regista manifesta il suo sconfinato talento in un contesto molto più descrittivo, nel quale prende il controllo di una ricostruzione storica maniacale e dettata da scenografie incredibili. Tarantino aveva già cambiato il corso della storia a suo piacimento, e questa volta lo rifà con un tocco molto più personale del solito, con una velata motivazione lasciata a piccole dosi in alcune scene specifiche lungo tutta la durata del film. Questo fa si che nel finale si sprigioni un delirio assoluto che va a completare con innovazione e sorpresa un quadro generale aperto fin dall'inizio dell'esperienza. Palese punto di forza del film è una totale sicurezza nell'approccio al film. Tarantino è totalmente a suo agio in un'opera che lo vede in pieno controllo del suo lavoro, a partire dall'immagine complessiva fino ad arrivare al minimo dettaglio. Non si può neanche dire che sia uno dei suoi film migliori, perché ormai ogni suo film è "uno dei suoi film migliori". Quello che è certo è che va a completare a pieni titoli una filmografia assolutamente leggendaria.
Sony Pictures, Columbia Pictures, and Quentin Tarantino's Once Upon a Time... In Hollywood is a very amazing film!!!

Only Tarantino could have made this good. Nothing really happens until the final half hour in a 160 minute picture, but do we care? This man could write the daily routine of an undertake and create a superb feature film. The dialogue is up there with some of the best that I have ever experienced. The visuals are amazing. It's clear that Tarantino put his all into this project, and it completely shows. Career-defining stuff from Pitt and DiCaprio, who sizzle together and excel apart. Robbie doesn't have much to do of interest in comparison and her moments in the spotlight are certainly a change of pace, but still emanate the same amount of fun. The rest of the cast also shines at so many various point that they escape description. The film would have been good with these baseline ingredients, but the ending is one of my favourites from any of Tarantino's. The glorious climax of brilliant humour and over-the-top violence will remain one of the greatest cinematic moments of the 21st century, and all of the film's self-indulgences pay off.
